title: Local notebook: Former Central thrower Ethan Thomas shatters UND shot put record
snippets: Apr. 8—GRAND FORKS — Former Grand Forks Central standout Ethan Thomas continues to turn heads in his true freshman season at UND. After destroying the UND indoor shot put record this winter, Thomas easily crushed the outdoor record recently, as well. At the Triton Invitational in La Jolla, Calif., Thomas threw a personal-best throw of 63 feet, 7.75 inches. The previous record was 58-10, set by ...
summary: Ethan Thomas, a freshman at UND and former Grand Forks Central standout, broke the UND outdoor shot put record at the Triton Invitational in La Jolla, California, with a throw of 63 feet, 7.75 inches. This surpassed the previous record of 58 feet, 10 inches. Thomas had previously set a new indoor shot put record at UND this winter, showcasing his exceptional talent in his first collegiate season.
titles: Local notebook: Former Central thrower Ethan Thomas shatters UND shot put record

title: Overall ski champion Brignone discharged from the hospital after breaking her leg
snippets: Overall World Cup skiing champion Federica Brignone was discharged from the hospital on Tuesday, five days after breaking multiple bones in her left leg in a giant slalom crash and undergoing surgery.  “I still don’t know how long it will take (to return),” Brignone told reporters as she sat in a wheelchair before leaving the La Madonnina clinic in Milan.  Brignone also tore her ACL, raising questions about her chances of competing at the home Olympics in 10 months.
summary: Federica Brignone, the overall World Cup skiing champion, was released from the hospital after a five-day stay due to a giant slalom crash that resulted in multiple broken bones in her left leg and a torn ACL. Following surgery at the La Madonnina clinic in Milan, Brignone's recovery timeline remains uncertain, casting doubt on her ability to compete in the Olympics in 10 months.
titles: Overall ski champion Brignone discharged from the hospital after breaking her leg

title: Watch These Supermicro Price Levels as Stock Soars After Tariff-Induced Selling
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Super Micro Computer shares jumped in early trading Tuesday, adding to an 11% gain yesterday, as investors bid up the server marker’s stock after a few days of big losses during the broader market sell-off.
  • The stock completed a bullish engulfing pattern in Monday’s trading session, potentially forming a bear trap.
  • Investors should watch major overhead areas on Supermicro's chart around $48 and $63, while also monitoring vital support levels near $26 and $17.


Super Micro Computer (SMCI) shares jumped in early trading Tuesday, adding to an 11% surge yesterday, as investors bid up the server marker’s stock after a few days of big losses during the broader market's tariff-fueled sell-off.

Sentiment surrounding the stock likely received a boost from J.P. Morgan analysts who recently pointed out that the company would only need to increase its global prices by 4%, based on the portion of its hardware that would be affected by tariffs.

Supermicro shares saw significant price swings in both directions during the first quarter as the company dealt with accounting issues that raised concerns of a potential Nasdaq delisting until the company met the exchange’s deadline to file several delayed financial reports in February. The stock was up 6% at around $35 in recent trading.

Below, we break down the technicals on Supermicro’s chart and identify major price levels that investors may be monitoring.

Potential Bear Trap

After gapping lower in late October, Supermicro shares oscillated within an orderly ascending channel until breaking down below the pattern’s lower trendline toward the end of last month.

However, despite falling to its lowest level since early February last week, the stock completed a bullish engulfing pattern in Monday’s trading session, potentially forming a bear trap—a trading event that lures investors to sell upon a breach of major support before the price makes a sudden move higher.

What’s more, Monday’s buying coincided with the relative strength index (RSI) rallying from a reading of around 35, the same level the indicator bottomed at in early February before the stock roughly doubled over a two-week period.

Let’s identify two major overhead areas to watch on Supermicro’s chart amid the potential for follow-through buying, and also point out vital support levels worth monitoring.

Major Overhead Areas to Watch

A decisive close back above the ascending channel’s lower trendline could trigger a rally to around $48. This level, currently just above the closely watched 200-day moving average, connects a range of comparable trading activity on the chart extending back to last year’s prominent August swing low.

Buying above this price could see the stock revisit the $63 area. Investors who have accumulated shares during the stock’s recent decline may decide to lock in profits in this region near a trendline that links last year's late-August peak with the February swing high.

Interestingly, this location also sits in the same vicinity as a projected bars pattern target that takes the stock’s sharp trend higher during February and overlays it from the low of yesterday’s bullish engulfing candle.

Vital Support Levels Worth Monitoring

A breach of the bullish engulfing candle's low could see Supermicro shares initially retrace to around $26, a location on the chart where they may attract support near the January trough and early-November countertrend high.

Finally, a breakdown below this level paves the way for a potential drop to $17. Investors may seek buy-and-hold opportunities in this region near the mid-November trough, which also marks the stock’s 52-week low.

The comments, opinions, and analyses expressed on Investopedia are for informational purposes only. Read our warranty and liability disclaimer for more info.

As of the date this article was written, the author does not own any of the above securities.
summary: Super Micro Computer (SMCI) shares experienced a significant increase, rising 11% in early trading on Tuesday after a previous 11% gain. This surge comes after the stock faced substantial losses during a broader market sell-off influenced by tariffs. Analysts from J.P. Morgan suggested that the company could offset tariff impacts by raising global prices by 4%. The stock's recent volatility is also tied to concerns about a potential Nasdaq delisting, which were alleviated when Supermicro met the filing deadline for delayed financial reports in February. The shares were trading up 6% at around
titles: Watch These Supermicro Price Levels as Stock Soars After Tariff-Induced Selling

title: CVS Stock Pops as Pharmacy Chain Improves Full-Year Outlook, Taps New Execs
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • CVS stock surged Tuesday after the company said it expects to meet or exceed its previous outlook for 2025.
  • This comes after the government said it will pay Medicare insurers, such as CVS' Aetna, more than previously expected.
  • CVS also announced new executives, including a CFO expected to start later this month.


CVS Health (CVS) shares jumped Tuesday after the company improved its full-year outlook and named a new chief financial officer.

The pharmacy and health insurance giant said it now expects to meet or exceed its adjusted earnings projection of $5.75 to $6 per share issued in February. Analysts expect $5.89 on average, according to Visible Alpha. 

CVS shares jumped over 8% in recent trading. The federal government also announced late Monday that it will pay Medicare insurers, such as CVS' Aetna, more than previously expected.

The company's shares are up about 55% year-to-date, making it the best-performing stock in the S&P 500 since the start of the year, after a difficult 2024. 

Along with its improved forecast, CVS announced the appointment of a new CFO, with former UPS (UPS) CFO Brian Newman set to take over the role effective April 21. The company also named Amy Compton-Phillips, who most recently served as chief physician executive of Press Ganey, its chief medical officer, effective May 19. These shakeups follow a CEO change in October that saw CVS veteran David Joyner take the helm.
summary: CVS Health's stock experienced an over 8% surge on Tuesday after the company announced it anticipates meeting or surpassing its 2025 earnings forecast of $5.75 to $6 per share. This positive outlook was bolstered by the federal government's decision to increase payments to Medicare insurers, including CVS' Aetna. Additionally, CVS introduced new executive appointments, naming former UPS CFO Brian Newman as its new CFO effective April 21, and Amy Compton-Phillips as chief medical officer starting May 19. The company's shares have risen approximately 55% year-to-date, positioning CVS as the top
titles: CVS Stock Pops as Pharmacy Chain Improves Full-Year Outlook, Taps New Execs

title: Treasury Secretary Bessent Says China Playing With 'Losing Hand'
snippets:
KEY TAKEAWAYS

  • Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in an interview Tuesday that the U.S. has the upper hand over China as the trade war intensifies.
  • "What do we lose by the Chinese raising tariffs on us?" Bessent said, "We export one-fifth to them of what they export to us, so that is a losing hand for them."
  • On Tuesday, China threatened to hit back further if President Donald Trump hikes U.S. import tariffs by an additional 50%.


Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in an interview Tuesday that the U.S. has the upper hand over China as the trade war intensifies.

"I think it was a big mistake, this Chinese escalation, because they're playing with a pair of twos," Bessent said on CNBC. "...What do we lose by the Chinese raising tariffs on us? We export one-fifth to them of what they export to us, so that is a losing hand for them."

On Tuesday, China threatened to hit back further if President Donald Trump hikes U.S. import tariffs by an additional 50%, saying it would "fight to the end."  

"I think you are going to see some very large countries with large trade deficits come forward very quickly," Bessent said. "If they come to the table with solid proposals, I think we can end up with some good deals."

Bessent told Fox Business on Monday that he expected Japan to get priority in trade talks "just because they came forward very quickly," which helped the Nikkei close 6% higher Tuesday.
summary: U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent claimed the U.S. holds an advantage in the escalating trade war with China, citing the imbalance in exports between the two nations. Bessent argued that China's decision to raise tariffs is a strategic error, given the U.S. exports significantly less to China than vice versa. This statement came amid threats from China to retaliate if the U.S. increases import tariffs by an additional 50%. Bessent also mentioned potential for positive trade deals with other large countries and highlighted Japan's proactive stance in trade talks, which positively impacted i
titles: Treasury Secretary Bessent Says China Playing With 'Losing Hand'

title: Smell-seeking drone uses moth antenna to follow a scent
snippets: A moth antenna can be integrated into the electronics of a drone to create a smell-seeking bio-hybrid – but it only detects the smell of a female moth
summary: Researchers have successfully integrated a moth antenna into drone electronics, creating a bio-hybrid device capable of detecting the specific scent of a female moth. This innovation marks a unique blend of biological components with technology, though its current application is limited to the identification of one particular smell.
titles: Smell-seeking drone uses moth antenna to follow a scent

titles: How long is a day on Uranus? Slightly longer than we thought, it seems

title: Trees capture toxic fingerprint of gold mining in the Amazon

summary: Scientists have discovered that mercury pollution, a byproduct of gold mining, is accumulating in trees. This finding offers a novel approach to track and monitor the environmental impact of gold mining operations by analyzing mercury levels in tree tissues.
titles: Trees capture toxic fingerprint of gold mining in the Amazon

title: Experimental medication helps treat cocaine addiction

summary: A new medication designed to help individuals with cocaine use disorder has shown promise in encouraging them to lower their cocaine intake. This development represents progress towards potentially the first approved drugs aimed at treating this specific disorder.
titles: Experimental medication helps treat cocaine addiction
